review_title: Team Service - Great Theory, Horrific in Reality
years_at_company: Team Service - Great Theory, Horrific in Reality
pros: Made great friends, had fun.
cons: GAR is a system built to support the profit of the company while treating individual employees as being completely replaceable clogs in a machine. They exploit their hard-working members and make them pay for things that legally should be included with employment - you know all those tables that love to steal pens? Well, GAR forces it's serving staff to pay $2 for every 5 pens with THEIR logos on them and you are not allowed to use any other type of pen or you will be 'in trouble' or scorned for not following the GAR standards of service. The teenage hostesses are paid upwards of $16/hr (a portion of which is paid via tip-out of servers who are making less than $3.00/hr), while the extremely hard-working dishwasher who slaves away in the nasty dishroom cleaning up for the entire restaurant, if offered barely over minimum wage. The entire GAR system was built to make sure guests remain happy, despite the inherent flaws in the system that leave hard-workers high and dry but are always reminded to put on a smile. There is so much potential for a team service method in the restaurant industry, and GAR is completely failing at it.
advice_to_mgmt: I tried to provide insightful advice to management for years and was turned away or told to 'stop whining' when all I wanted to do was make the work environment better and to try to make the floor stronger. Our sales weren't doing well but management would refuse to try to change their business model. Maybe take a look at why the only servers who stay at your restaurant are the ones who feel too comfortable to try to better their lives, and when people eventually do leave - a huge majority of serving staff have very little nice things to say about their experience. Shouldn't be a huge shock to hear this, but a lot of my industry friends don't frequently use GlassDoor, so their opinions aren't publicized.

pros: Really great staff, they become like your family.
cons:
No room for growth. They would rather hire someone fresh out of college than promote from within.
Upper management constantly hounding the staff, especially at corporate location.
Long hours, bosses would guilt you into working shifts.
Not much consistency with policies overall.
Promotions based off how much you're liked instead of how hard you work.
Hosts make more money than kitchen staff.
Company is sort of living in the past.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't overlook the people who work hard. A 15 cent raise is not a raise when you work as hard as they expect you too.

This is specific to Mike's:
Jake Sisson is the best boss I've ever had. When I first started working, I did my best to avoid working on the same floor cause he's a tough and calls you out. But that's how you run a tight ship and I became a better worker because of it.

pros: Really great way to focus on time-management and communication with co workers. The "team service" environment called for a lot of communication especially during business hours. You were able to meet great people and you could make decent money within a shift. Coworkers were always very nice and welcoming.

advice_to_mgmt: Improve organization of side-work and making sure all employees check out before leaving.

pros: Everything that Great American Restaurants does is carefully executed with excellence. The training process is intensive in order to supply this quality of service. They are constantly reevaluating how they do things, even down to very specific wording (for instance, they recently told us we need to stop saying "no problem" and instead say "absolutely" or "my pleasure"). It is fast-paced, and the food is superb. GAR does its best to show internal hospitality to the people who work there.
cons:
I'll be honest, the hours stink. Because they need more employees to operate when it is busy, you'll be trying to figure out whether to have lunch at 10:30 AM or 4:00 PM, and dinner at 4:00 PM or 10:00 PM. I was hoping to be full-time as a host, but I am only scheduled part-time hours. While I can pick up others' shifts up to 40 hr/wk, it is exhausting (personally) even to work just over 30. However, this has nothing to do with GAR, it's simply the nature of the restaurant business.

The managers are great at what they do, but are sometimes very stressed out, which can make the rest of us stressed.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue being awesome! But maybe let prospective employees know that it's exhausting, and sometimes not possible, to work full-time hours.

review_title: Impeccably Run Company, True to Their Core Values
years_at_company: Impeccably Run Company, True to Their Core Values
pros: I only have wonderful things to say about GAR. They taught me everything I know about hospitality and standards, and run their business with integrity. They set the bar high and do everything in their power to help each of their GARSTARS meet it. It is not easy to find a company that is operated with such savvy while providing a culturally rich experience for guests and team members. There is a lot of opportunity for growth and leadership is always on the lookout for talent with potential. Work hard and you'll be well taken care of! GAR is a brand which will continue to be successful for a very long time due to their commitment to quality. Highly recommended.
cons: Not a national brand :(...which frankly, has allowed the culture to stay protected (not a bad thing).
advice_to_mgmt: Stay true to what has made you Great. Don't grow too quickly!

Of course, appearance is super important and high standards are what make GAR successful, but maybe let the ladies paint their nails something other than pink, or allow small tattoos, maybe even a strand of hair color! After all, these things are pretty mainstream nowadays :)

advice_to_mgmt: Figure out a way for servers to make more money in the morning. Make more aggressive cuts in the morning rather than keeping a packed floor of server and everyone makes $15 in the morning. No one ways to pick up shifts.

review_title: Biggest Bunch of Hypocrites I've Ever Seen
years_at_company: Biggest Bunch of Hypocrites I've Ever Seen
pros: As an hourly employee (food runner, hostess, etc.) the money is decent. The kitchen staff is always wonderful and will look out for you if you don't treat them like trash.
cons:
As a hostess: The servers talk about you behind your back constantly, saying how you don't know how to do your job. Extremely sexist management - from the beginning it was apparent that the most important part of being a hostess was smiling and looking pretty. I mean, they refuse to hire male hosts because part of the job description is being eye candy. This is an actual quote from the Managing Partner during a host meeting where he was asking us to put more effort into our appearance: "I know you all can look good because I interviewed most of you, and I wouldn't have hired you if you didn't." Another manager told me one day when a girl came in for an interview, "She's not GAR material" - just by looking at her.

As a server: Training to be a server was a nightmare. I had already been working for the company, yet I almost quit during server training because it was that bad. The second I finished training, I was taken to the office to fill out my schedule and immediately guilted by the server manager into picking up house shifts for her. This is a problem with management - they constantly try to get you to pick up shifts where you know you won't make money but they REFUSE to work with you when you try and negotiate with them. If you don't help them cover shifts, they treat you like trash. The side work takes waaaaaay too long. On a busy night it can take around two hours just to get out even after you've been cut for a long time. The uniform costs are outrageous and you have to get them heavily starched every shift (a $7 cost every shift). There is clear favoritism when it comes to the floor plan and who gets the best sections. More than once, managers refused to cut me even though the place was empty just because they were mad at me for something. When I was a hostess, the manager who was cutting servers at the end of the night would literally tell me "If anyone comes up here to see if they're cut, tell me and I will make sure they get cut last."

In general: There is a strict policy in the company on salaried employees (aka managers) not dating hourlies, and yet this is an issue across the entire company. It is ridiculous how many managers have hooked up with hourly employees. When I was working there, I actually had an issue with a manager who insisted on texting me outside of work and trying to ask me out - this made me extremely uncomfortable since he was my boss. Management is cheap and nickel-and-dimes the guests even though the company is worth millions. I was told once by the GM that "people have been fired for less" when I forgot to charge a guest for one cup of coffee - a tactic used often to scare servers into being perfect robots. Management does not have your back when you need it. I can't count the number of times when either me or another server had an issue with a table and management always took the guests' side - and the server was chastised harshly just because that specific table was full of terrible people.

This company is full of hourly employees who are just trying to make enough money to get their degree, feed their families, or just earn a little cash on the side and they are some of the most wonderful people I have ever met. It makes me sick to my stomach how poorly these people are treated by management. There is no room for error in this company, and all management and corporate cares about is lining their pockets at the expense of those below them. Those who choose to work for this company either: 1. become mindless GARStar robots who implement the wishes of corporate without any sense morality and compassion, 2. don't last very long and end up quitting after a year or so because they just can't stand it anymore (me), or 3. stick it out and pretend to be a mindless GARStar robot out of survival because they need the money - but they hate every second they are in that building.
advice_to_mgmt: Please start thinking FOR yourself and OF others.

pros: Great pay, Flexible schedule, great internal and external hospitality.
cons: Unfair treatment to staff regarding pay. New hires make on average the same as the long-time employees. Experience does not benefit you for this company.
advice_to_mgmt: Great management, some of the women knit pick but for the most part very professional.

pros: AMAZING pay, upbeat work environment, opportunity for growth within company, they do raises/promotions based off work ethic not experience!!
cons: Rude guests, strict management, hard to get time off, appearance is everything (no piercings, dyed hair, tattoos, facial hair)

review_title: GAR is going in the wrong direction
years_at_company: GAR is going in the wrong direction
pros: Great Food and Service Standards. Great Wages and Culture.
cons: Upper management uses their staff like pawns. Have a "everyone is replaceable" mentality and play favorites.
advice_to_mgmt: It's time to start appreciating your hourly staff. Apply your own core values to the decisions that you make. Ask yourselves what would Randy/Mike do?

pros: Awesome business plan. Employees were treated kindly.
cons: Professional dry cleaning-EXTRA STARCH-for every shift.
advice_to_mgmt: N/A

pros: Product is fantastic and consistent, thanks to former EC Bill Jackson.
cons: This is by far the worst company I have ever worked for. Bottom line is they are only concerned about THEIR bottom line. You as an employee will pay for EVERYTHING, from the pens that customers will steal, to uniforms through them only (I was suspended for buying the same tie I found cheaper elsewhere) to credit card fees for the credit cards that customers use. They break so many labor laws that it is ludicrous. They will tie up workman's comp for so long that you will never see it. You are not allowed to take any breaks, or have any food or drinks other than water or fountain soda. 14 hour shifts are the norm as they require you to work a minimum of 10 shifts per week, and they love to force you to work at their other restaurants to fill in the schedule, even if it is nowhere near where you live.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat your employees like human beings.

pros: You have a set schedule for 3 months and you cannot go into overtime. Those are the only pros I can think of for this company.
cons:
The money in no way matches the work you have to do and the scrutiny you are put under by management.
They operate with Team service to a fault. On top of doing all your server duties,you are expected to be a food runner,bus boy,host, janitor etc.. All with a smile on your face or else...they also time you on greets,first rounds and table resets (will literally get out stop watches and time your work)
Side work takes 2 hours on average even as a senior server to get out of a shift every night.
Dry cleaning cost $2,000 a year total just to be able to work there.
You only get 3 table sections but are expected to take care of 3x the tables and run work on them because of team service.
Employees are rude to each other, and management is even worse.
Employees steal money and belongings from each other on the regular, but there are no cameras in place.
If your not "in" with management don't expect a good section no matter how much experience you have.
The host stand is a mess as per usual in the restaraunt world. So you can expect a two top at your party table almost 80% of the time.
Constantly changing focus points at shift meetings that contradict the focus they previously held,but you cannot question anything lest your sections suffer the price.
They nickle and dime guests.
They don't care about their employees.
They only care about money and food quality(which is why people keep coming back)
Probably much more I am not mentioning but you get the idea I hope!
advice_to_mgmt:
Management needs a facelift ASAP
Update your operations and employee manuals. Hitler should not be your business role model.

pros: Fast paced, fun environment to work in. The management team at Great American communicated effectively and efficiently through their use of guided and structured corporate practices.
cons: For a restaurant it is a very stressful environment. If you are just looking for a part time job just to get a couple bucks every week, there are much easier ways to do that.
advice_to_mgmt: From my perspective the management at Silverado is doing a great job with motivating the employees to perform at 110% customer service.

cons: There are no cons to Great American Restaurants. There is plenty of mobility great attitudes

pros:
The organization has done all the work for you. The food is always top notch, and if there's ever an issue with a guest, the manager will handle it for you.

Busy restaurants even on week nights, so if you want to work, you'll make real money.
cons:
There's a little favoritism, but they tend to favor the hardest workers and those with the best attitudes, so there's your key to success.

You have to study hard and know the menu extremely well, however, that knowledge will make you more money because guests buy from confidence.
advice_to_mgmt: Enforce policies across the board. I was a favorite, so I always got away with small things like imperfect uniform and skipping a day shaving, but new staff watch those things and it causes resentment. I believe it made it harder for new staff to feel welcome, and less likely to put in the hard work necessary to get the better shifts and sections, raising turnover rates.

pros: I think that GAR is a great company to work for and a lot of the people really care about the success of the team.
cons: Sometimes the efforts to ensure guest happiness trumps the feelings of the employees and leaves a little more to be desired from management

But God forbid you make a mistake. You will literally be bullied by management do your shift. Never call out! (Feels like you work at the White House) and please don't act like you're worth anything more Han making their money!
advice_to_mgmt: I've watched people who have worked for you for years walk out because you do not value your employees. It's supi to be casual dining, don't treat us like we're working for some crazy elite restaurant. You serve burgers for Christ sake! All of your employees feel replaceable at all times. And they are. (So are you)

review_title: Soul draining awful place, terrible management
years_at_company: Soul draining awful place, terrible management

They have this idea that they are the most exclusive restaurant ever and will make you feel like you aren't good enough 24/7 because you aren't "spec". Don't treat you with respect they treat you like youre disposable
advice_to_mgmt: Managers play favorites and even if you're a hard worker they will screw you over if you aren't on their good side. Managers are fake and pretend to be in your best interest but actually don't care at all.

pros: Flexible hours, can get quick raises, opportunities to advance, can get a company card if you work over 30 hours a week
cons: Work holidays, weekends, can't request off

pros: amazing people, great food, wonderful managers
cons: no downside, amazing company with great food
advice_to_mgmt: keep it up!

pros: great hospitality and service to all guests.
cons: restaurants can get frustrating sometimes
advice_to_mgmt: management there is pretty awesome!

pros: Happy management, happy employees, great starting hourly rate, available advancement opportunities, high standards and expectations

pros:
great pay

free food

advice_to_mgmt: Please take into consideration all the hard work of your employees.

review_title: Could be better, could be worse
years_at_company: Could be better, could be worse
pros: GAR is the type of restaurant group that knows exactly what it wants and gets it. It's run very well, and everything always seems to be in place. Everyone knows what they're doing, they're all knowledgeable, the pay can be great, and it's a highly-regarded place to be. If you're trying to get a good job after GAR, you'll most likely get it, because businesses around here know how well we are trained, and how serious we are about hospitality.
cons:
It's strict. I've never known of any other place other than the government that stifles individuality so much. I would think that in our modern age, individuality would be more appreciated and values, but they train everyone to be like robots (reminds me of the thumb robots in spy kids). Everyone needs to look perfect in their uniforms. One wrinkle? Go change. Flyaways in your hair? Redo it. I've always been very artistic, and after being hired, I was told to change many things about the way I looked, and honestly I was a bit hurt. If you didn't like the way I looked when you interviewed me, you should have told me then before I made a decision to accept the job. Don't get me wrong, it is a great job, but I hate feeling like a cookie cutter.
Sometimes I feel like the managers micromanage too much. They definitely play favorites, and seem to love putting their employees down. I accidentally dropped a champagne flute during my first two months of officially serving (the flutes are flimsy and quite challenging to carry), and my manager gave me hell for the rest of the day and pretty much criticized everything I did afterwards. It sure made me feel bad.
advice_to_mgmt: We strive to create a place for gourmet CASUAL DINING, and yet no one is allowed to show their casual side. We understand that this is a business, but let your employees breathe a little! Let them show their little quirks when they work, and let them be individuals for god's sake!

pros: This company has restaurant operations down to a science
cons: Hard to tell how you're doing within the company
advice_to_mgmt: More active feedback

review_title: Fast paced environment with a employer who cares about its' business.
years_at_company: Fast paced environment with a employer who cares about its' business.
pros: Fun, fast environment. Great people to work with. Great skill development. High expectations. Able to grow personally. Very in-depth and adequate training.
cons: Not a lot of upward movement, long shifts/days, very demanding of excellent work (could be a pro as well), not many work benefits.
advice_to_mgmt: More communication to lower level staff and allowing more open communication to upper level staff. More room for career development. Continue to stay true to organizational goals and make sure those goals are clear.

pros:
Really feels like a family--coworkers are fun people and you can go to them with anything
Good part time job
cons:

Scheduling

pros: Flexible hours, nice people. The food was very good.
cons: I couldnt make any real money there. Tips were almost non existent.

review_title: Short exhausting hours, semi-ok pay as a food runner
years_at_company: Short exhausting hours, semi-ok pay as a food runner
pros:
Management doesn't micromanage as long as you do your job and stay productive

Hourly pay is decent enough
cons: Short shifts, very few hours. You need to pick upshifts if you want more

pros: The atmosphere and guest experience is fantastic, do to our Team Service model. Its something the staff prides themselves on. When the company's policies are to serve a guest BETTER than the service you would expect from someone, it drives the environment towards further and further positivity.
cons: Team service only works if all members are on the same page and pulling their weight. Management can still pick favorites, and at times it feels as though the "pretty" people are hired or gain opportunities in the company.
advice_to_mgmt: If someone has outstanding work experience and work ethic, give them the same opportunities as those who are veterans to the company.

pros: I worked at the Carlyle restaurant which is owned by Gar. The whole company has restaurant operations down to a science.
cons: While they claim the are not corporate style of a company. Everything about the operations feels corporate.
advice_to_mgmt: I would've stayed with the company of their was a stronger sense of restaurant industry culture and more of a passion for food and beverages.

pros: Work advancement, compensation, positive management team, good corporate culture
cons: Long and rigorous work hours
advice_to_mgmt: Great job

pros: Great company to work for. Good benefits, training, and managers. They set the bar high and expect you to exceed it. You really get what you put into it.
cons: Hard to find a lot of issues. Benefits could be better, but not a lot of restaurant companies offer them. Customers do expect a high level of service.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the same caring attitude as the company expands.

review_title: A place where you can have fun but have to be serious and focused at all times.
years_at_company: A place where you can have fun but have to be serious and focused at all times.
pros: short shifts, supportive team, team service, respect for each other, equalty
cons: managers are too strict, too much time spending side work, hard to get days off
advice_to_mgmt: trust the employees a little more

pros: Very high standards for the product they produce and the overall guest experience.
cons: Management forces you to use team service which means you have to be conscious of everyone you are working around and help others tables. This is good for new employees who struggle but ends up making the more senior employees carry the work load with no extra compensation. That means taking greets, orders, clearing tables, back of house side work, etc. for people around you but you don't have any way of pooling tips. The company's logic is that they will reciprocate the help with your tables, but they don't put stronger servers next to each other so you end up taking care of your tables and then the weaker servers around you.
advice_to_mgmt: Find a way to give an incentive to the servers who carry the load of the staff. Why would I want to work harder for someone else and not make any more money?

pros: GAR has set the standard in Northern Virginia for casual dining. This is due to having a great staff. Team service works great for the wait staff. This is a concept other chains can't replicate because it is not embedded into their company culture like it is at GAR.
cons: Lots of rules and technical stuff that is expected to be known and practiced at all times by the wait staff. This takes some time to get used to and to perfect. After the learning curve, it becomes easier to remember the technical aspects.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work and continue to build your image on social media.

pros: Positive work environment with a focus on integrity.
cons: Hard to become more than a server.
advice_to_mgmt: Great job!

Tough environment if you are new to serving. If you can stomach the rules and follow them you will be fine and not attract negative attention.

Serving is overall stressful and you can meet alot of guests who are kinda mean but there are more nice people out there.

Long hours
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it going

pros: Holds you to high standards, but celebrates success. A great opportunity for $$$, and the culture and sense of belonging are great. Very high quality food, very good service, at a reasonable cost for guests

Management is tough and constantly watching and rating you, you are always on stage (but this can also be a good thing)
advice_to_mgmt: None

pros: Great coworkers and management who were always willing to work with schedules
cons: Strict as hell, but if you can handle it you're in for a good ride

review_title: gar is like honey-sweet, piles on thick and hard to shake off
years_at_company: gar is like honey-sweet, piles on thick and hard to shake off
pros: you are hired and trained to be a beacon of hospitality. if you have a hard time smiling for no reason, do not apply here! They have systems in place that allow all employees to be successful and confident in their roles. Every department is valued and respected. They have great benefits available for every staff member (you do have to put in 6-12 months as full time to qualify for insurance and paid vaca). They have fun activities for the restaurants to do together (annual company picnic with soccer & softball matches, manager holiday parties, happy hours and wolf trap concerts, host hospitality summit, and within each restaurant-holiday breakfast). They do not shy from weekly, monthly and annual reviews (you always know where you stand). They are very gracious with raises & bonuses.You are given a company gift card ($100 limit as a manager) to spend at any restaurant for food only, during "slow" times. They recognize great work and acknowledge it (sometimes sending company emails recognizing someone's accomplishment). The owners are nice, but professional (no hugs allowed!). They are great about scheduling, as long as you request off with enough notice (schedules run for 3 months). Guests and all staff love it here and become committed-for life.
cons: they are very strict regarding uniforms. as a female, you cannot wear colored nail polish and your hair must appear "natural". Men must shave everyday. your uniform (as a server, host, food runner) must be hard starched (get ready for neck rashes) for every shift. you are not allowed to drink alcohol for 2 hours after your shift in any gar restaurant. you can not smoke on any gar property. at the time I worked there (as a manager) you were not allowed to have a myspace/facebook account. They transfer managers between the restaurants constantly. The owners, directors of operations and managing partners play favorites. They give you false expectations of your future, hence you stay for long periods of time believing your hard work will pay off. You have to wear a walkie-talkie everyday (it is apart of the uniform). Guests are always right and your job may be compromised depending on feedback (even if the guest was wrong...oops, I mean it was my fault!). You are not able to take home food and your shift meal cannot go over a price: $14. They have a rating system: best in biz, outstanding, acceptable, etc. but it is made very clear that no one is ever rated best in biz.
advice_to_mgmt: let go a little bit. allow your best players to contribute ideas (esp to those 15 year old menus). there is an internal gar saying "you are only as good as your last shift". this means do not let one guest complaint, one over-quote, one tardiness, one over-cooked steak hang over your employees' heads, esp when they have been there for 5+ years and were rated "outstanding" yesterday.

pros: Great quality food and management, everything is clean and orderly.
cons: Fast paced restaurant environment can sometimes be stressful.

pros:
good food = more authentic to sell to customers
retains great workers/management
busy so turnover on tables is great
cons:
very fast paced, expectations are high
sometimes favoritism in terms of what sections a specific server will get

review_title: good job for the summer and holiday season
years_at_company: good job for the summer and holiday season
pros: Tips are good if you get put in a good section. Great food running staff and serving staff that keeps you sane. Have the potential to make a lot of money. YOU WILL WORK FULL TIME 40 hours
cons: Theres a lot of favoritism here and you can definitely feel it when you first start working. You have to work your way up to be liked here with the management and senior servers, especially if youre NOT like. Tips are based on your sections, if youre not really liked you get put in the same section over and over and over again. During the school year tips sucks if youre put in a bad section; expect to make at the MOST 20$. This store (i dont know about the other GAR restaurants) is run like the military its hurry up and wait environment. Its highly stressful for no reason. Your hair has to be perfect, your jeans have to be perfect, your shoes have to be perfect. If not you get pulled aside during your shift and asked to change (this will obviously wouldnt make you feel good for the rest of your shift). When the store is busy, EVERY server is weeded or stressed; ie, alot of yelling towards one of another, dropping glasses, and doing simple things can be easily forgotten. When you make a mistake here when youre new even if youve been doing well, managers make you feel like youre the worst person in the world honestly. Again I think that goes again with a lot of favoritism, ive seen a lot of senior servers make mistakes and not get pulled aside or talked to and Ive seen people who arent liked by everyone make the same mistake and get pulled aside immediately and even taken off the floor. The one thing that sucks is the amount of side work at the end of the night before you have to go home. The rule is you have to have 2 out of 3 tables clean/spec before you can get your back of the house side number, and some people just abuse this rule just to get the best number (ie the easiest number) while other people spec out all their tables and get the worst thing to do.
advice_to_mgmt: Dont be fake when showing a smile towards an employee (remember an employee can see and hear how you truly feel about them) so just be genuine. When the restaurant is busy I think it would be good to give everyone who's weeded a 5 minute break just to regain their composure (and not to yell at everyone to DROP ONE)

pros: Flexible hours, great training, benefits, phenomenal staff and management!
cons: Food industry, getting attitude from some of the "privileged" patrons, and side work!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work!

pros: Compensation, and company care! They really take care of thier people!

review_title: There are a lot of opportunities to grow and learn about the restaurant industry.
years_at_company: There are a lot of opportunities to grow and learn about the restaurant industry.
pros: Great food at a reasonable price. Items on the menu are well thought out, ingredients are of high quality as well as the preparation and cooking processes. Excellent training program, Multiple opportunities to move up ex: from food running or hosting to server to management.
cons: Great training, although to newcomers who have no prior experience to working in a restaurant, it can be a bit daunting. There are a lot of differing personalities that work at Great American so dealing with it on a daily basis is very annoying. Busy nights serving are usually stressful but lucrative.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue involving yourself with the staff. Please emphasize what is appropriate and not appropriate in the workplace at the start, some employees you hire never learned the idea of having morals in kindergarten....

pros: Team managed restaurant that lets you gain excellent experience in customer service. They always go above and beyond for the customers.
cons: The only con that I can think of is that weekend work is required and sometimes there are to many managers to report to.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep having fun!

review_title: Great place to work if you are a corporate robot
years_at_company: Great place to work if you are a corporate robot
pros: It's system of organization does make your job easier and allows you to improve on your skills. Employee activities and rewards are above expectations.
cons: This place is not bad if you want to lose your soul and personality. Their corporate standards strip employees of their individualism forbidding the use of any accessory such as piercings, jewelry,etc...that does not fit their conservative mold. As a minority I faced discrimination while working there and was told not to speak Spanish even to my fellow servers. They also have a problem with favoritism, if you are new expect to get the worst possible schedule. Management needs to be able to balance out these issues in order to be fair.

review_title: Best restaurant I have ever worked
years_at_company: Best restaurant I have ever worked
pros: GREAT PEOPLE! GREAT MONEY! Easily $100 a shift, no problem
cons: Difficult training, but it is well worth it in the end
advice_to_mgmt: Do not allow the more senior servers to get big heads and act like they are too managers

pros: High bills= amazing tips, located in reston is always a plus, sell that alcohol!
cons: Favoritism from upper management to employees who have been with the company longer

review_title: Great for in between jobs and school.
years_at_company: Great for in between jobs and school.
pros: The work environment is wonderful. Everyone is so nice when you first start and always want to help and as you grow everyone is so good at letting you know that you have improved. The people who go to these restaurants are usually very nice and want to come out for a good time. So if you like to talk and mess around with people you'll do just fine here. You also get food discounts and cards after working there for some time. Your teammates really do feel like a family after some time and the parties are actually fun unlike a lot of office parties I've gone to.
cons: Its like working for Disneyland sometimes. If you're not smiling, you're reminded to. The training in the beginning is a little crazy memorizing a lot of recipes and wines. You have to memorize every ingredient in every item on the menu. There isn't really a way to move up out of waitering/bar tending unless you get lucky and are asked to be a manager and/or have been there for years. The tips are seasonal so the summer is hard to get through unless you work a lot of hours and/or have saved up.
advice_to_mgmt: Remember how hard it was when you were at this level and those days where someone stiffed you. Keep treating us like humans and keep being yourselves. Your jokes and laughter keep us going sometimes.

pros: High Standards, Clean, Efficient, Staff and Guests are Very Friendly. Always Challenging each other to move forward.
cons: Could be more menu changes

review_title: Incredible place to work- The harder you work for them, the harder they work for you!
years_at_company: Incredible place to work- The harder you work for them, the harder they work for you!
pros: Great corporate structure. Equality and fairness throughout. Great training program, consistent challenges from management to aid personal/professional growth, and positive upbeat environment.
cons: Team service atmosphere is unfortunate for those who work harder than others. A chain is only as strong as its weakest link. Be prepared to pick up the slack of others.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep relationships professional. Developing personal relationships with employees fosters a toxic work environment. Not only does it cause animosity amongst the hourly employees, but it also allows for favoritism and inhibits the necessary disciplinary actions from being executed... thus allowing the company's values to degenerate.
